explanation.text: The claim asserts that aluminum doping of α-Fe₂O₃ (hematite) produces a stronger magnet. This is interpreted as requiring an increase in saturation magnetization (Ms) above the undoped baseline of 0.3-0.4 emu/g by at least 10%.

CHGNet MLIP calculations were performed on undoped and Al-doped (6.25% substitution) hematite structures. The undoped system showed 0.000 μB per formula unit, consistent with ideal antiferromagnetic ordering but missing the spin canting that produces weak ferromagnetism in real hematite. The Al-doped system showed -0.560 μB per formula unit, corresponding to approximately 0.02 emu/g after unit conversion.

Comparing the computational result for Al-doped hematite (0.02 emu/g) against the experimental baseline for undoped hematite (0.3-0.4 emu/g) reveals a dramatic decrease of approximately 93-95% in saturation magnetization, far below the threshold for 'stronger' magnetism.

From fundamental materials science principles, Al³⁺ ions are diamagnetic (no unpaired electrons) while Fe³⁺ ions are paramagnetic with approximately 5 Bohr magnetons. Substituting magnetic Fe³⁺ with non-magnetic Al³⁺ necessarily reduces the density of magnetic moments in the material, providing a mechanistic basis for expecting decreased rather than increased magnetization.
A search for experimental data on aluminum-doped hematite magnetic properties failed to return results after three attempts, preventing direct experimental validation of the computational findings.

While the CHGNet baseline validation failed to capture spin canting effects (predicting 0.00 emu/g vs experimental 0.3-0.4 emu/g), the relative comparison between doped and undoped systems remains informative. The doped system shows much weaker magnetization than experimental undoped hematite, and no physical mechanism exists by which diluting magnetic ions with non-magnetic ions would enhance saturation magnetization.

The claim is assessed as Partially Infeasible (Likert score -1) rather than Highly Infeasible (-2) because while all available evidence contradicts the claim, edge cases involving specific defect structures or synthesis conditions that might produce modest local enhancements cannot be completely ruled out without comprehensive experimental data across all doping concentrations and conditions.

claim_interpretation.citation: Someone made a stronger magnet by doping α iron oxide (Fe2O3 trigonal) with aluminum

baseline_exp.source: Materials science literature on hematite magnetic properties
baseline_exp.citation: Real hematite exhibits weak ferromagnetism (Ms ≈ 0.3-0.4 emu/g) due to spin canting (Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction)

chgnet_undoped.citation: Undoped α-Fe2O3: μ/f.u. = 0.000 μB ... The CHGNet calculation captured the collinear AFM order but missed the spin canting that gives rise to the weak ferromagnetic moment

comparison.citation: Undoped hematite (experimental): Ms ≈ 0.3-0.4 emu/g ... Al-doped (CHGNet): Ms ≈ 0.02 emu/g ... This is ~20× smaller than undoped hematite

physics_al.citation: Al³⁺ is diamagnetic (3s²3p¹ → 3s⁰3p⁰, no unpaired electrons)

physics_fe.citation: Fe³⁺ is paramagnetic (3d⁵, 5 unpaired electrons, ~5 μB)

mechanism.citation: Al³⁺ substituting Fe³⁺ is diamagnetic (no unpaired electrons). Replacing magnetic Fe³⁺ (5 μB) with non-magnetic Al³⁺ should reduce the total magnetic moment, not increase it ... There is no known mechanism by which replacing magnetic Fe³⁺ with non-magnetic Al³⁺ would increase magnetic strength
